title.narrative: Responding to the trauma casualties and advocating for upholding the International Humanitarian Law in Gaza

description.narrative: Action A: Man made crisis and natural disasters,Action C: DIPECHO

The funding from DG ECHO will specifically contribute to maintaining and enhancing the pre-hospital management of trauma patients sustained during the demonstrations of the Great March of Return in order to decrease risk of death as well as the physical and mental health consequences amongst injured cases. Secondly, it will ensure access to healthcare for trauma and non-trauma patients admitted in the emergency departments of key Ministry of Health (MoH)-designated trauma hospitals. Thirdly, it will also strengthen the protection of health care.The total number of people that will benefit from the ECHO funding will be 357,295 people, across the Gaza Strip, until December 2020.WHO will support pre-hospital trauma management through enhanced coordination, procurement and distribution of medical supplies and improvement of quality of care for trauma management at the ten TSPs established by the MoH and the PRCS. WHO will also support six MoH Mental Health Emergency Teams in Gaza to provide timely and quality community (MHPSS services for injured people. WHO will also work to improve monitoring of attacks on health care, provision of protection training and equipment to medical staff involved in the pre-hospital management of trauma causalities, and enhanced advocacy at local, regional and international levels.Annex 1 MR9_14.1.20 MR/04/03 May 2020: Due to COVID 19 pandemic WHO reached an agreement with ECHO to reprogram funds remaining under the budget category “Supplies, commodities, materials” to fund activities that scale up the capacity of the health system for testing, case management and IPC in response to COVID19 pandemic MR/05/01 November 2020: following COVID-19 community outbreak WHO reached an agreement with local ECHO Representative to submit an NCE to continue working on the limb reconstruction center in Nasser Hospital-Gaza

title.narrative: Projet de RRC inclusive pour le renforcement de capacité des populations vulnérables de la côte ouest de Madagascar

description.narrative: Action A: Man made crisis and natural disasters,Action B: Emergency Toolbox

L'action vise la mise en oeuvre d'un mécanisme pour les préparations et réponses aux catastrophes au sein des Districts de Mahajanga I et II et de Marovoay dans la région de Boeny au Nord-Ouest de Madagascar. Le choix de ces 3 districts a été fait en considération de l'approche bassin versant. En effet, le fleuve Betsiboka qui traverse ces 3 districts est l'un des plus grands fleuves de Madagascar avec 2 confluents et plus de 4 affluents et un bassin versant de 49 000km². L'insuffisance d'actions efficaces pour gérer ce bassin versant provoque des inondations conséquentes et récurrentes dans ces 3 districts après le passage d'un cyclone ou simplement lors d'avènement de fortes pluies. L'approche globale du projet sera également inclusive, sensible au genre et intégrée. Elle s'articulera également autour des priorités internationales auxquelles Madagascar adhère. Les indices de risque INFORM pour le pays sont de 7,4 et 7.7 pour les cyclones et inondations. Si le littoral Est est souvent le plus impacté, ces 5 dernières années les localités plus à l'ouest et au nord-ouest, tels que les Districts de Mahajanga I et II et de Marovoay sont régulièrement touchés. La DGM indique que d'ici 2100 (« Le changement Climatique à Madagascar » 2008) les tendances sont à l'augmentation du nombre des cyclones intenses et à leur changement de trajectoire, se déplaçant plus au nord. Les Districts de Mahajanga I et II et de Marovoay, sont directement concernés par ces tendances. Le consortium CARE, SAF FJKM et HI renforcera les capacités de ces populations à faire face à ces aléas en apportant son expertise en RRC, en développement intégré et en inclusion et pourra capitaliser sur ses expériences antérieures dans le cadre du HIP 2017.

title.narrative: Supporting basic education for Syrian refugees and Egyptian host communities in Greater Cairo, Alexandria and Damietta

description.narrative: Action A: Man made crisis and natural disasters

The action will be extended for six months, allowing the support to extend for the first half of the next academic year. The extension is responding to the adverse impact of COVID-19 on the grant, and the resulting suspension of all project activities since March 2020. The COVID-19 specific response interventions are planned to be held immediately during the original 28 months (starting May 2020) while the additional 6 months starting October 2020 will allow continuation of implementation of the original activities in Syrian learning centres (SLCs) . After the recent MoE decision to cancel al planned activities with teachers and children in public schools for the next academic year 2020-2021, cash grants and light repairs are the only two activities continuing in public schools, and cancelled activities in public schools are replaced with new activities in the SLCs added across the different results. Proposed activities include providing learning centres’ educators with trainings on interactive online learning, child protection and anti-bullying, distributing back-to-school kits to enrolled children in targeted learning centres, shaping peace clubs with children using Games of Human Rights manual, forming parenting circles to tackle various parenting needs , and equipping SLCs more regularly with sterilization and hygiene kits considering COVID-19. Additionally, to mitigate the impacts of COVID-19 on children’s safety and education, this action will also be supporting each SLCs to first develop a Safety protocol to ensure safe return to education of children, teachers and other education personnel and second a Contingency plan that will include actions to be taken by SLCs management committees to ensure continuity of learning in case children’s education will be disrupted by COVID19 outbreak in the centre (more details in section 4 of the ESF).

title.narrative: Reaching Vulnerable Refugee Children from Syria and Palestine, including vulnerable Host Community Children, in Lebanon with Pathways and Opportunities to Quality Education and Protection Services

description.narrative: Action A: Man made crisis and natural disasters

The activities proposed in this action will run from June 2018-May 2021 and contains a MR for HIP 2020 funds; the MR will allow NRC to extend non-formal education activities with support of the local partner, Amel Association for additional Basic Literacy and Numeracy programming. NRC will maintain outreach capacity and continuously improve referral pathways for children. NRC will continue to produce relevant documentation that will be used for advocacy purposes and to better target our intervention in reaching the most marginalized groups. NRC will implement non-formal education activities as outlined in the Ministry of Education and Higher Education (MEHE) strategy "Reaching All Children with Education". Activities include Community-Based Early Childhood Education for children of pre-school age; and Basic Literacy and Numeracy for out of school children (OOSC).NRC will particularly focus on out-of-school children, facilitating learning pathways and internal or external referral whenever needed, building on continuous coordination with ECHO partners and interventions as well as broader inter-sector coordination, in order to mitigate barriers to education through a multi-sectoral integrated response.NRC up until end 2019 continued to host the Lebanon Humanitarian INGO Forum; LHIF activities have been added as part of the first MR. The aim was to enable continued provision of an independent platform for INGOs in Lebanon to advocate on key issues of common interest, more effectively engage in response coordination and leadership and help ensure humanitarian space is maintained.

title.narrative: Support trauma, secondary and primary health care services for affected populations in Hassakeh, Ar-Raqqa and Deir-ez-zor (North East Syria).

description.narrative: Action A: Man made crisis and natural disasters

This project proposal aims to address gaps in health services and health supply chain to support life-saving and essential health services provided by INGOs operating in North East Syria The project will be operationalized and coordinated from WHO regional office in Cairo with strong support from the logistics platform at the WHO Iraq office and WoS Coordinator to strengthen health coordination and needs-based distribution and response. The main focus of the proposal is to support health supply chain of required medical kits to strengthen service provision by partners operating in NES, the proposal will also aim to strengthen health coordination and logistic capacity in Iraq.

title.narrative: Emergency assistance and resilience building for the conflict affected population of Nashabye.

description.narrative: Action A: Man made crisis and natural disasters

The Action aims to provide life saving assistance and build the resilience of 12,000 conflict affected people including IDPs, returnees and the most vulnerable inhabitants of Nashabye sub-district, Eastern Ghouta. Here, widespread deprivation and vulnerability as a result of a 5-year-long siege are compounded by constrained freedom of movement and humanitarian access. Nashabye is now destination of a vast influx of lDPs and returnees, whose physical and financial access to food and other basic necessities is very limited, with consequent adoption of negative coping mechanisms. The Action adopts a community-based approach to targeting, implementation and monitoring and fosters beneficiaries' participation in project decision making. It pays special attention to the most vulnerable including the displaced, female headed households, the elderly and people living with diseases and disabilities. Main sectors covered are food security and livelihoods, nutrition and hygiene promotion, and protection, including provision of psychological first aid and referral services. Through collective advocacy efforts, the Action will support expanded humanitarian access to hard to reach areas.MR2 - Please see Annex 1

title.narrative: Increased access to education and protection for vulnerable Syrian and non-Syrian refugee children and families in Turkey

description.narrative: Action A: Man made crisis and natural disasters

As the Syria Crisis enters its 7th year, Turkey has become home to the largest number of refugees in the world - approximately 3.4 million. More than 3.1 million Syrian refugees, including over 1.4 million children, with just over 324,000 non-Syrians registered from primarily Afghanistan and Iraq. As part of the Facility for Refugees in Turkey, WFP, the Turkish Red Crescent (TRC), the Ministry of Family and Social Policies (MOFSP), funded by ECHO started the roll-out of the Emergency Social Safety Net (ESSN),a cash assistance programme helping vulnerable refugees cover basic needs such as food, rent, utilities, medicine, and clothing in the last quarter of 2016. ESSN has reached 1 million beneficiaries as of September 2017.Complementing the ESSN, UNICEF has partnered with TRC, MOFSP and MONE to extend the existing national Conditional Cash Transfer for Education (CCTE) Programme to cover Syrian and other refugees in Turkey, aiming to increase access to education for refugee children in a protective environment. The programme completed its 1st cash payments to beneficiaries in May 2017. The programme has been appreciated by education actors, both Government and civil society,for its contribution towards decreasing financial barriers for vulnerable families are critical to keeping children in school. UNICEF is proposing to continue supporting the integration of refugee children into the CCTE for an additional 12 months. This proposal also includes the continuation of the strategic child protection component through targeted outreach ensuring that the most vulnerable refugee children and their families are able to continue participating in the cash transfer program and are identified, assessed and referred to complementary child protection services.UNICEF plans to reach 350,000 children with this programme by August 2019.MR02:The programme plans to reach 495,000 children by Sept 2019,including ALP students.MR03; MR04

title.narrative: Enhancing protection of at-risk and marginalized refugees in Turkey through improved access to services

description.narrative: Action A: Man made crisis and natural disasters

Diakonie Katastrophenhilfe (DKH) has been responding regionally to the Syrian crisis since 2012. Through its partner Support to Life (STL) in Turkey, DKH has provided emergency assistance ranging from food aid and NFI distributions to cash based interventions, psychosocial support and case management. The humanitarian protection framework recognizes every individual's fundamental rights and the obligation of state and humanitarian actors to remove any obstacles to accessing the rights to identity and documentation, right to health, education and to live free of discrimination. In Turkey, state institutions still lack adequate capacities and resources as well as services vary significantly from place to place and without the necessary language skills, information and awareness refugees continue to face difficulties in accessing services, or face protection risks. STL will support refugees' access to services via provision of specialized and non-specialized support, improved capacities of government and non-government service providers and empowered community members. Based on vulnerability criteria, selected individuals will be assisted to overcome obstacles through information provision and supported in accessing services as per their right under the Temporary and International Protection Regime. Community volunteers will be trained to provide information, identify and refer cases. State service providers will receive training and support to increase their capacities. Additionally, information about service availability and challenges will feed into the analysis of protection services and will be used for advocacy towards stakeholders. Starting from March 2020, the Covid-19 pandemic effected not only public health and livelihoods but also vulnerable populations on access to basic rights and service and enhanced the protection risks. STL will provide one time cash assistance based on predetermined criteria in order to address immediate protection risks.
